cot.cot_output:

2. In Europe, the most common form of megalithic architecture is the stone circle.

Answer:
Stone circles

        The most common form of megalithic architecture in Europe is the portal tomb, which consists of upright stones with one or more large flat capstones forming a roof. These structures, often known as "dolmens," are believed to have been primarily used as burial sites during the Neolithic and late Stone Age periods. The megalithic structures in the northwest of France are considered the oldest in Europe based on radiocarbon dating. Additionally, Nordic megalith architecture, primarily found in Scandinavia and North Germany, emerged between 3500 and 2800 BC and was a product of the Funnelbeaker culture. The architectural style involves large slabs of stone arranged to form various structures such as dolmens, passage graves, and stone cists. Furthermore, large ceremonial complexes with carved megalithic orthostats have been discovered in eastern Turkey, dating back to the 9th millennium BC, but it is unclear if any European megalithic traditions are derived from them.
